;;我;;NSIDE ATOMS;，事情发展得很快。电子围绕原子核变焦，在不到阿秒的时间内改变其位置或能量。阿托秒是十亿分之一秒的十亿分之一，这是一个如此短的时间单位，以至于一秒钟内的阿托秒与 138 亿年前大爆炸以来的秒数一样多。

;

;因此，观察电子飞来飞去是很棘手的。然而，今年的诺贝尔物理学奖获得者找到了一种方法来做到这一点。皮埃尔·阿戈斯蒂尼（Pierre Agostini）、费伦茨·克劳斯（Ferenc Krausz）和安妮·勒惠利尔（Anne L'Huillier）表明，可以制造出能够快速闪烁的激光器，以致每个光脉冲仅持续几百阿秒。这些光脉冲可用于拍摄电子运动的快照。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;<超快激光器的工作原理与频闪灯的工作原理相同，可以帮助捕捉日常生活中快速移动物体的有用图像。例如，蜂鸟每秒可以拍打翅膀 80 次。对于人眼来说，这看起来很模糊。不过，使用高速相机和闪烁速度快于蜂鸟翅膀拍打速度的闪光灯，就可以拍摄飞行中的鸟的详细照片。

;

;生成足够短的光脉冲以观察电子始于 L'Huillier 教授的工作。 1987 年，她在巴黎附近的萨克雷核研究中心工作，试验激光和氩气或氖气等惰性气体。她发现激光将能量传递给气体原子，使它们的电子松散。当这些电子最终被重新捕获时，它们以光的形式释放能量。

;

;这些光波依次相互作用。当它们的峰值重合时，它们就会变得更加强烈。然而，当一个波的波峰遇到另一个波的波谷时，光的强度就会下降。有时，如果光波以正确的方式相互作用，它们会产生仅持续几百阿秒的紫外线脉冲。

;

;2001 年，同样在法国工作的 Pierre Agostini 建造了 L' 教授。 Huillier 对一项可行技术的观察，设计了一种产生一系列光脉冲的方法，每个脉冲持续 250 阿秒。大约在同一时间，克劳斯博士在维也纳独立工作，成功地产生了一系列持续时间为 650 阿托秒的脉冲。

;

;如今，科学家已将光脉冲进一步缩短，降至数十阿秒。这些超快的迪斯科灯仍然不够快，无法冻结原子周围轨道上的电子，但模糊的相机总比没有相机好。在阿秒光出现之前，科学家只能谈论电子在特定时间处于特定位置的概率。这些脉冲还可用于测量电子与原子核的结合程度，以及在化学反应过程中电子被撬开所需的时间。

;

;其他应用还很遥远。阿秒光脉冲可能有助于创造超快电子器件，其中半导体在绝缘和导电状态之间的切换速度比现在快得多。这些脉冲还可用于推动大分子，然后大分子继续发射取决于其精确化学组成的特征辐射。例如，它可以用来分析血液样本，以期找出哪怕是最小的疾病标志物。 ;■;

; Wed, 04 Oct 2023 20:27:02 +0800 Kevin McCarthy’s sacking deepens the chaos in American government | United Stateshttps://www.economist.com/united-states/2023/10/04/the-sacking-of-kevin-mccarthy-will-make-supporting-ukraine-harder ;

;;K;;evin McCarthy; 作为美国众议院议长的任期以原来的方式结束开始：以完全羞辱的方式。 10 月 3 日，国会下议院议员罢免了他们的领导人，这在美国历史上尚属首次。尽管获得了 221 名众议院共和党人中 210 名的支持，;八名强硬派;与 208 名民主党人联手解雇了麦卡锡先生。此后不久，这位前议长宣布他不会试图重新获得这一头衔。未来几周可能会变得混乱，而国会功能失调这一章节的后果将远远超出国会山。

;

;麦卡锡先生赢得议长木槌后，一场令人尴尬的驱逐似乎就在眼前。在一月。作为 15 轮投票后与顽固的共和党人达成的协议的一部分，麦卡锡先​​生同意允许一名国会议员在任何时间、以任何理由要求投票罢免他。来自佛罗里达州的一位精心打扮的代表马特·盖茨(Matt Gaetz)一段时间以来一直威胁要提出所谓的撤离动议。这位前议长最近与民主党达成交易以避免政府关门，这将他推向了悬崖边。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;尽管麦卡锡先生犯了种种错误，但他在任职期间克服了微薄的利润。六月，他成功提高了债务上限，以避免不必要的强制违约。然后，9 月 30 日，他在最后一刻推动了两党达成协议，推迟代价高昂的政府关门。下一位发言人可能会发现这项工作更加困难，即使没有像麦卡锡先生那样难以驾驭的共和党中的一些人所承受的包袱。

;

;当前的任务将是为政府提供资金。避免政府关门的协议只能让政府维持到 11 月 17 日。如果不迅速采取行动，麦卡锡的继任者将在上任几周后负责监督工厂关闭。温和派共和党人和强硬派之间的巨大分歧，特别是在众议院自由核心小组中，不会仅仅因为会议由一位新面孔主持而消失。

;

;对乌克兰的援助未包含在政府资助中为了安抚强硬派而达成的协议，是美国境外人士最关心的问题。在宣布离职的新闻发布会上，麦卡锡将弗拉基米尔·普京与阿道夫·希特勒进行了比较，并表示当今的世界让他想起了 1930 年代。他重申了对乌克兰的支持，并正确地批评了乔·拜登总统过去在武装该国方面的犹豫不决。

;

;但共和党会议的一些成员已经开始;反对进一步提供资金;。麦卡锡提出了一个交换条件，即如果民主党帮助通过加强美国漏洞百出的边境的政策，那么对基辅政府的援助就会获得批准。 ;乌克兰的支持者; 在国会中，他们在参众两院均占绝对多数，他们正在推动一项投票，以保证在 2024 年美国总统选举之前为这个饱受战争蹂躏的国家提供资金。执行这一立法针可能比避免政府关门更加困难。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这项任务将落在谁身上尚不清楚。由麦卡锡亲自挑选的北卡罗来纳州共和党人帕特里克·麦克亨利将担任代理议长，并将监督麦卡锡继任者的选举。周二晚上与麦卡锡先生会面的国会议员表示，共和党人计划在 10 月 10 日举行候选人论坛，并在第二天进行投票。但真正的问题是，共和党会议中谁有足够的心理素质来完成这项工作，并且仍然疯狂地寻求它。

;

;没有人预计会像保罗·瑞安 (Paul Ryan) 在 2015 年取代约翰·博纳 (John Boehner) 担任议长那样迅速达成共识。据报道，众议院共和党第二号人物史蒂夫·斯卡利斯 (Steve Scalise) 已开始权衡支持率。司法委员会主席吉姆·乔丹作为前自由核心小组主席享有盛誉，他成功地与麦卡锡的盟友进行了富有成效的合作。凯文·赫恩 (Kevin Hern) 领导着共和党研究委员会，该委员会的成员包括众议院共和党的大多数成员。

;

;混乱和阴谋将像一部以华盛顿为背景的电视剧《白宫风云》的任何一集一样有趣。对于希望政府保持开放的美国人，或者依靠美国的力量和慷慨来维持生存斗争的乌克兰人来说，这并不能带来什么安慰。 ;■;

;;三岁时，Artem 被诊断出患有严重自闭症。他在海滨城市 ;乌克兰东南部的马里乌波尔;。他的父亲阿纳托利现年 54 岁，是一位戏剧导演，身材魁梧，性格开朗，喜欢喝伏特加。阿乔姆的母亲安娜也 54 岁，身材娇小，留着精灵般的发型，为了照顾他，她放弃了剧院服装部裁缝的工作。她还照顾与他们住在一起的母亲，她年纪太大了，她还记得;第二次世界大战;。她喜欢讲述她如何在院子里发现一辆坦克和一名德国士兵用她母亲最好的披肩清洁枪的故事。

;

;阿尔乔姆不会说话，也不像其他孩子一样去上学。他的父母试图为他的世界架起一座桥梁。当他十几岁的时候，他们设法教了他几个音节。 “Ya-ha”代表;ya khochu;，意思是“我想要”； “pi”，代表;pyit;，“饮料”； “pa”代表;pamagi，;“help”，当阿尔乔姆在系鞋带或穿衣服时遇到困难时，他会使用这个词。

;

;阿尔乔姆喜欢走路，经常一次走几个小时。但当家人不得不在公交车站排队或在商店等待时，他变得焦躁不安：他发现做事之间的差距令人沮丧和难以理解。他的父母会说“Padazhdi，padazhdi”，意思是“等待”，Artem 学会了重复这个自我安慰的咒语。 “Zhdi，zhdi，zhdi”。

;

;;Artem 不会说话，也不像其他孩子一样去上学。他的父母试图为他的世界架起一座桥梁;

;

;Artem 只吃非常有限的食物：薄脆面包、香蕉、苹果和一种名为 Marichka 的干酪甜点，上面有一张照片一个女孩在浴缸里。他喜欢听欢快的流行音乐和观看他收藏的音乐<小>;DVD;。不知何故，尽管无法阅读，他还是学会了在平板电脑上浏览互联网，找到他最喜欢的音乐视频。他通过流水舒缓身心，并会花几个小时坐在淋浴下。

;

;死记硬背、常规、养生、重复：这就是这个家庭 20 年的生活方式。然后在 2022 年 2 月 24 日，一切都改变了。战争初期，电力被切断：没有收音机、<小>;电视;、互联网或手机连接。然后没有水、没有煤气、没有暖气。没有办法逃脱：家里没有汽车，没有公共汽车，没有任何信息。他们的公寓楼有一个地下室，但你必须爬下梯子才能到达。阿尔乔姆无法被哄到那里，而他的祖母已经 92 岁了，几乎无法行走。阿纳托利说，他们最好都呆在自己的公寓里。如果他们被杀，他们至少会一起死。

;;

;起初，安娜继续带阿尔乔姆出去散步，但很快战斗就迫近了。阿纳托利从附近的一根立管取水，直到水干为止。他从炮击中受损的商店里拿走食物，并寻找制作炉子的木材。随后乌克兰士兵从他家所在的地区撤出。有一天，安娜向窗外望去，看到四辆俄罗斯坦克停在自家院子里。

;

;Artem 的平板电脑没有电，没有水洗澡，也没有 Marichka 甜点。他的父母用毯子把他裹起来以防寒冷，他躺在床上，手里抓着音乐<小>;DVD;，摇头的方式让他的父母认为他正在脑子里播放歌曲。

;

;一枚炮弹在他们的街区附近爆炸，造成两人死亡。阿纳托利在一家破烂的商店里发现了几公斤干瘪的苹果，这很有帮助，因为阿尔乔姆几乎停止了进食。阿纳托利在一家被洗劫一空的药房里抢救木材时，发现了一堆药片。包装上写着他们患有自闭症，因为他们已经用完了阿尔乔姆常用的药物，所以他们开始给他服用这些药物。

;

;;死记硬背、常规、制度、重复：这就是这个家庭的生活方式20年。然后在 2022 年 2 月 24 日，一切都变了;

;

;当炸弹坠落、子弹破裂时，他的父母向 Artem 解释道，“Streliayut”：他们正在射击。 “Strelyia-ut，”阿尔乔姆一遍又一遍地说道。这是他唯一能完整发音的词。当爆炸声非常大时，阿尔乔姆会咬住自己的手并尖叫。有一次，他嚎叫了两天，直到失声。

;

;4 月 2 日，Artem 的祖母因生病并停止进食而去世。他们将她埋在院子里。

;

;;俄罗斯人在入侵后几天内就包围了这座城市；即使是那些有车的人也几乎没有时间走出去。俄罗斯人安排的一些巴士将人们带到东部的顿涅茨克，这是自 2014 年以来一直被占领的国家的一部分。那些留下来的人——躲在潮湿的地下室里，寻找食物和燃料，冒着生命危险在炮击中取水亲眼目睹亲人被杀、残害、跨过尸体——与外界完全隔绝。没有人知道两个月的战斗中有多少数万名平民丧生。

;;;;

;四月，俄罗斯行政人员出现在这座城市，尽管他们仍在继续轰炸躲藏在亚佐夫斯塔尔钢铁厂的最后一支乌克兰军队。他们用发电机为一些手机信号塔供电，这样居民就可以捕捉到间歇性的信号，并向不知道自己是生是死的亲人发送信息。运水车被派出，人道主义援助中心被建立来分发食品和衣物——人们排了几个小时的队来登记，然后等了两周才拿到一袋罐头食品。安装在卡车上的移动屏幕播放俄罗斯新闻。士兵们挨家挨户寻找与乌克兰武装部队有联系的人；他们在街上拦住人们，让他们脱掉衣服检查是否有爱国纹身。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;阿纳托利和安娜的领地缩小到了几个邻居，他们共用楼梯和入口处的炉子。几个星期以来，安娜一直没有住在隔壁街上的哥哥和他妻子的消息。五月，战斗平息后，阿纳托利和安娜决定离开这座城市。在此之前，他们必须接受俄罗斯当局的“过滤”、背景调查，并获得盖章的“许可”声明。他们前往其中一个“过滤点”出示文件并接受讯问。他们等待时阿尔乔姆哭着咬着自己的手，但他们还是拿到了通行证。阿纳托利找到了一个愿意带他们穿越前线的司机，尽管不能持续几天——司机必须找到地方买汽油。

;

;5月20日，安娜去了一个新兴的小市场。附近——她听说有人在卖阿尔乔姆的马里奇卡甜点。当她离开时，阿纳托利被捕。两名穿着军装、没有佩戴徽章的男子敲响了他们公寓的门。当阿纳托利打开它时，有人用枪指着他的肚子。尽管天气温暖，阿尔乔姆仍然裹着毯子躺在床上——寒冷的冬天，他的父母曾警告他不要让毯子滑落，但现在他不肯松开毯子。

;;

;军人搜查了公寓，没收了阿纳托利的手机和阿尔乔姆的平板电脑。其中一人推开了阿尔乔姆卧室的门。 “你傻吗？这么热的天，你怎么还盖着两条毯子躺着？”阿乔姆对这种咄咄逼人的语气感到苦恼，开始哭泣。阿纳托利解释说，他的儿子患有自闭症，不能让他一个人呆着。这些人让他请邻居和阿尔乔姆住在一起，然后他们把阿纳托利带走了。

;

;;A;春天来了到了夏天，马里乌波尔的情况有所好转。电力恢复了，阿尔乔姆可以再次观看音乐视频。尽管没有热水，但供水系统已重新接通，因此安娜在炉子上加热了锅，为阿乔姆洗澡。食品店在废墟建筑的空洞里开张了：阿尔乔姆每天吃两条面包，体重增加了。安娜试图带他去散步，但他不想再出去了。

;

;马里乌波尔现在处于俄罗斯的控制之下。俄罗斯人设立了市政府，由俄罗斯支持的分裂主义顿涅茨克人民共和国（<小>;DNR;）的行政人员和来自亲俄罗斯政党的地方议员组成。人们需要获得许可才能从事医生、护士或卫生工程师的工作——任何由政府支付工资的工作。其他人则从事从倒塌建筑物中挖掘尸体和清理瓦砾的工作。后来，一些人帮助重建工作。

;

;;当爆炸声非常大时，阿尔乔姆会咬住自己的手并尖叫。有一次他嚎叫了两天，直到失声;

;

;城市入口处的大马里乌波尔标志被重新漆成俄罗斯红、蓝、白。剧院周围竖起了一块屏幕，2022 年 3 月，数百名避难的乌克兰人在俄罗斯的炮击中丧生。广告牌竖起，宣扬乌克兰与俄罗斯的兄弟情谊。纪念大饥荒（20 世纪 30 年代斯大林强加给乌克兰的饥荒）的纪念碑被拆除。根据碑文，为亚历山大·涅夫斯基 (Alexander Nevsky) 树立了一座新雕像，这位王子保卫中世纪的罗斯，对抗“来自与俄罗斯今天作战的国家的敌人”。安娜和阿尔乔姆居住的街道被重新命名为俄语。

;

;货币现在是卢布。人们求助于黑市货币交易商，他们利用该国无人居住地区的中介机构来获取乌克兰银行账户中的格里夫纳。交易员们以折扣价将这些兑换成现金卢布。学校用俄语授课，课程删除了乌克兰历史，教师被送去接受再教育，孩子们被要求进行军事演习。

;;;

;俄罗斯人迅速推出了一个管理框架。持有俄罗斯文件并不是必须的，但它变得越来越有用。人们排队申请俄罗斯护照，重新登记他们的财产（两个邻居必须证明你的所有权和居住地），申请养老金和福利。乌克兰政府继续向马里乌波尔居民支付某些种类的养老金；其他人被阻止。就在新年前夕，乌克兰当局发放了阿尔乔姆几个月的伤残津贴，安娜获得了一笔意外之财：总计约 1000 美元。 2023 年春季，她支付了约 2,000 卢布（20 美元）的费用，向俄罗斯当局将 Artem 登记为残疾人，这样他就可以获得每月 7,000 卢布的福利。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;安娜的哥哥和他的妻子似乎对俄罗斯官僚机构的效率印象深刻。战前，他们花了几个月的时间收集申请乌克兰国家养老金的复杂过程的文件。相比之下，一旦他们获得俄罗斯护照，他们就会立即收到俄罗斯养老金。这对夫妇和马里乌波尔的许多人一样，观看俄罗斯<小>;电视;新闻。安娜的兄弟开始重复俄罗斯的虚假信息：乌克兰军队在剧院埋设了地雷，导致许多人死亡，并且他们利用马里乌波尔的平民作为人盾。安娜感到困惑：当他们还是孩子的时候，她的哥哥鼓励她在学校学习乌克兰语。现在他们又发生了好几场大战。她告诉他，如果他继续胡言乱语，他们就会停止说话。

;

;;阿纳托利和安娜的领域缩小到几个邻居，他们共用楼梯和入口处的炉子;;

;;W;七月份我在基辅时，与许多逃离马里乌波尔的人交谈过。有些人，比如曾担任该市市长的瓦迪姆·博伊琴科(Vadym Boychenko)，在战争初期就成功逃脱了；其他人最近才离开。他们描述了两名马里乌波尔人——一名流亡，一名被占领。在入侵之前，马里乌波尔的人口约为五十万。 Boychenko 估计马里乌波尔目前有 15 万人居住。其中三分之一是自占领开始以来在俄罗斯政府的激励下从俄罗斯和中亚移居到那里的人，俄罗斯政府为他们提供了可观的工资和难民废弃公寓的住宿。 Around 150,000 residents of the city are displaced within Ukraine, 120,000 are in Europe and 50,000 in Russia.

;;

;All the Mariupolans I met in Kyiv spoke with great anguish at the divide between them and family members who are still in the city. Some said that, after all the trauma of war, their relatives no longer wanted to talk about Russia or Ukraine – they just wanted to get on with their lives. Diana, who worked in the culture department of the local council and escaped with her 12-year-old son, told me she has a completely different relationship now with her mother and brother who remain in Mariupol. Her mother, nostalgic for the days of the Soviet Union, says things like, “Russia is much larger and more powerful, they will win, just as they beat the Nazis. Russia will always win.” Her brother has a job in construction and tells her Ukraine is being colonised by Poland.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Denis, a nightclub manager in his 30s, said he can't understand why his younger brother in Mariupol, “an intelligent person with critical faculties”, believes what he sees on Russian ;TV;. “He tells me: 'I don't want to live in a country that cannot protect me. Ukraine has nothing, no weapons, no big army.' He has become brainwashed.” Denis has tried to reason with him many times, but his brother counters: “You weren't here. You didn't see your neighbours' bodies lying in the street. Why didn't you come? Why didn't you help us? Neither you nor your country came to help us.”' Denis spoke with great pain, tears in his eyes. “I really have no answer to this,” he told me. The brothers have not spoken since April.

;

;Petro Andryushchenko is a pollster and political adviser to Mayor Boychenko. He remains in contact with friends in different municipal departments inside Mariupol and gleans information from Telegram channels. He has managed algorithmically to track public opinion in Mariupol over the past months.

;;;;

;Andryushchenko said that even before the occupation, the city was roughly 20% pro-Russian and 20% pro-Ukrainian. The remaining 60% did not much care either way. “We call them the fridges,” he said. “For these people, what matters is not which flag is flying over the council building, it's what's in their fridge.” A year ago, he calculated that the majority of these people had been persuaded by the Russian narrative. Services were being reconnected by the occupiers and there was a sense that things were getting better. Now, he said, pro-Russian opinion was being eroded by people's experience of corruption and repression. Mariupolans are complaining about low salaries, preferential treatment being given to incomers, haphazard internet connection, poor-quality produce in the markets, kiosks selling vodka on every corner and the sour taste of ;DNR;-manufactured cigarettes.

;

;For Andryushchenko, those who stayed in Mariupol had made a choice. “We understand and they understand that they are paying taxes to Russia which buys the weapons that kill us.” It was as if Mariupol had been unplugged from Ukraine and plugged into Russia. He didn't think that the relationship between people who stayed and people who left could be repaired. “I think it's for ever for all of us.”

;

;;A;natoly was charged with incitement of hatred and enmity for a series of Facebook posts he had made during the first days of the invasion, before the internet was cut. One was a picture of a cartoon couple holding hands in front of a burning Kremlin.

;

;The investigating officer was a young woman from the prosecution department of the ;DNR;. When she first questioned him, in May 2022, she filled out her protocol form in Russian, but switched easily to Ukrainian to read out the offending Facebook posts. Anatoly complimented her on her accent. Without thinking, Anatoly recalled, she replied in Ukrainian, “Oh thank you, I used to get top marks for Ukrainian at school,” and then realised that she had admitted her pride in her prowess at a language she ought to treat with disdain. She swore. Anatoly's case was complicated when Russia officially annexed the ;DNR; on October 4th 2022 because the offences he had been charged with were not subject to custodial sentences under Russian law. Still it took six months before he was released on parole.

;

;When Anatoly finally arrived home in March, Artem looked at him in the doorway, turned away and went into his room. Anna hugged her husband tightly and asked him: “When are we leaving?”

;

;“You said you didn't want to leave your home,” he reminded her.

;

;“This is not my home any more,” said Anna.

;;

;Artem was upset his father had been away for so long, but a few days after Anatoly's return he tugged his hand to show he was ready to resume their bedtime routine, when Anatoly would lie down with his son before he went to sleep. Some weeks later though, Anna found Artem ripping up old family photographs.

;

;Anatoly was struck by how much Mariupol had changed since he'd been in prison. There was now electricity, gas and cold running water. Buildings had been razed, and whole blocks reduced to vacant patches of land. There were long waiting lists for compensation and for new apartments. The sounds of construction was everywhere – people complained that the repairs to damaged buildings were shoddy. But elsewhere housing developments with sea views were going up to accommodate new arrivals: Russians, Chechens, Kazakhs. The family's apartment block was still mostly empty, but two Uzbek families had moved onto the floor below, and half-a-dozen rowdy Chechen men were living in a flat on the ground floor.

;

;;People in Mariupol complained, but a mood of resignation hung over the city. They said that the Ukrainians had abandoned Mariupol. They were in Russia now and Russia would take care of them;

;

;Russian news carried no mention of the explosions that people could hear, as Ukrainians shelled military targets on the outskirts of the city. Anna and her brother avoided talking about politics, but he continued in his pro-Russian stance.

;

;There was a sense of mistrust, between the occupying authorities and Mariupolans, and between the residents themselves. From time to time someone spray-painted a Ukrainian flag on a wall or graffitied praise to Ukrainian defenders. But no one dared talk openly. Informers were everywhere. Every week people disappeared. No one knew where they were taken.

;

;;I;n spring this year, the family began to make plans to leave. Anatoly, Anna and Artem needed Russian passports so they could travel easily through Russia back to Ukraine. The passport application office in Mariupol was inundated. But Anatoly had a friend who knew a policeman in another town where there were fewer applicants. “Thank God you can bribe them [policemen],” he told Anna when he gave her the news they could jump the queue.

;;;

;There were, however, several Artem-shaped obstacles. First they needed a passport photo, but the face had to have a neutral expression and Artem always grinned when he saw a camera. They had obtained special dispensation for Artem's Ukrainian passport picture; now when Anatoly explained the problem, the photographer winked and (against all regulations) Photoshopped a closed top lip. It tickled Anatoly that his son was smiling in his Ukrainian passport and frowning in his Russian passport.

;

;Artem screamed when the technician yanked his wrist over the electronic fingerprint reader. Then they were told Artem would have to declare, out loud, an oath to uphold the laws and constitution of the Russian Federation. Anatoly spent some time persuading officials that the oath could just be read and signed – and that Anna could act on behalf of Artem.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;With all the waiting and the strange people with barking voices, Artem became agitated and started to scream. His hysteria, his parents saw, was a kind of “superpower”: the officials soon got out their stamps to clear the family as soon as possible. Oddly, their passports bore the words, “Issued by the Crimean passport authority”. In this topsy-turvy world, time and place were in flux. One friend of theirs had received a passport in Mariupol that was issued “in Zhdanov”, the Soviet name for Mariupol.

;

;Anatoly and Anna packed in secret so that Artem would not become anxious. They booked a taxi and set off at 7pm, hoping that Artem would sleep on the way. (He did not.) At the checkpoint outside Mariupol the soldiers looked at their documents and waved them through. The family in the car in front of them was turned away because they had Ukrainian passports.

;

;;Denis said he can't understand why his younger brother in Mariupol, “an intelligent person with critical faculties”, believes what he sees on Russian TV. “He has become brainwashed.”;

;

;They drove through southern Russia and the next morning they arrived at an informal crossing-point on the Russian-Ukrainian border. Artillery thundered in the distance. Anatoly mustered all the calm he could and told Artem it was only fireworks.

;

;Anatoly was worried a hard drive he had brought with him would arouse suspicion at the Russian checkpoint. Once again Artem saved them, howling and biting his hands in frustration at the hold-up. The guards threw their bags back at them and waved them through.

;

;They had to walk almost two kilometres along a track, hauling their bags in the boiling heat. When they finally saw a Ukrainian border guard sitting beside a small hut, Anatoly stopped and took out his phone to film the moment of deliverance. Artem made a lowing sound and uttered syllables he had never said before: “Jo-jo!” His parents did not know what it meant, but they understood that he was happy. ;■;

;

;;F;;OR 73 YEARS; Turkey has been a member of the Council of Europe, the organisation established in 1949, long before there was a European Union, to protect fundamental human rights on European soil in the wake of the second world war. Recent developments suggest it may not be a member for much longer.

;

;Council members agree to abide by the European Convention on Human Rights and to accept the jurisdiction of its Strasbourg-based court, the European Court of Human Rights (;ECHR;).上周，法院得出结论，Yuksel Yalcinkaya 被指控策划了 2016 年未遂政变，并因使用名为 Bylock 的即时通讯应用程序而被“果断”判处六年监禁。 This, it said, constituted “systemic violations” of the right to a fair trial.; Around 8,500 other people have lodged similar complaints with the court against their convictions, and up to 100,000 have been identified as Bylock users, and therefore potential coup-plotters, by the Turkish authorities. The ;ECHR; ordered Turkey to take measures to rectify the violations.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Two days after the judgment in Mr Yalcinkaya's case, Turkey's highest appeals court overturned an appeal by Osman Kavala, a businessman and philanthropist handed a full-life sentence in April 2022. He had been convicted of attempting to overthrow the government because of his alleged involvement in anti-government protests (pictured) at Gezi Park in central Istanbul in 2013 and in the attempted coup. The ;ECHR; had previously ruled that there were “serious issues” with Mr Kavala's conviction.

;

;In all, Turkish applicants have 24,700 cases pending at the ;ECHR;, nearly a third of the total.总统雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安 (Recep Tayyip Erdogan) 越来越认为法院是一个令人讨厌的人，其判决可以被忽视。未遂政变引发了对土耳其司法机构的大规模清洗。 Around 7,000 judges and prosecutors were sacked and replaced with political loyalists or newly graduated novices.

;

;In his speech at the opening of parliament on October 1st, Mr Erdogan described the Bylock judgment as “the straw that broke the camel's back”. “Even England, a founding member of the system, could not tolerate the ;ECHR;,” he added, an apparent reference to a push by some members of Britain's governing Conservative Party to withdraw from the convention. “We can neither respect the decisions of institutions aligned with terrorist organisations, nor listen to what they say.”

;

;The antagonism is mutual. Frank Schwabe, the head of the German parliamentary delegation to the Council of Europe, says that the council's parliamentary assembly will increase its pressure to launch infringement procedures against member states that ignore ;ECHR ;rulings. “The Council of Europe must make clear that any state which persistently refuses to implement a final judgment of the ;ECHR; cannot continue to be a member of this institution,” he says.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Only two members have ever left the council. 1969 年，希腊军政府退出，以避免即将被驱逐（1974 年恢复民主后，该国又重新回归）。去年3月，俄罗斯在入侵乌克兰后被驱逐。土耳其于 1950 年加入该理事会，成为第 13 个成员国，目前是人口最多的国家。 Its withdrawal would be an even bigger reverse for the body than Russia's expulsion, and perhaps provide encouragement to; ECHR;-sceptics in London.

;

;For Turks, withdrawal from the convention and the jurisdiction of the Strasbourg court would remove their last means of redress in their sclerotic and unreliable legal system. It would also mark a definite end to Turkey's long-stalled candidacy for ;EU; membership;任何国家在加入欧盟之前必须先成为理事会成员，而理事会成员现在已成为成员资格的正式法律要求。 The ;EU; itself recognises the jurisdiction of the ;ECHR;.

;

;Mr Erdogan has been trying to play nice with his European allies since his narrow election victory in May, in the hope of wooing back the foreign investors that have deserted Turkey in recent years.但在国内，他通过反击西方的谴责赢得了选票。 With crucial local elections due next March, he may reckon that Turkey's council membership is worth sacrificing.;■;

;;T;;he Manchester ;Central Convention Complex began life as a grand railway terminus. As the Conservative Party gathered there for its annual conference, which began on October 1st, awkward questions swirled about ;the future of ;HS;2;, Britain's beleaguered high-speed train line—and specifically whether the line's northern leg, from Birmingham to Manchester, would be amputated.难怪总理里希·苏纳克 (Rishi Sunak) 想要将话题从火车转向汽车。

;

;Mr Sunak declared before the conference started that he was “slamming the brakes on the war on motorists”. 20英里/小时限速区的使用将受到限制，公交专用道和停车规则将得到调整。坑洼比呼啸而过的火车更重要。 That isn't just a parochial agenda for the leader of a ;G;7 country;这也是一种误导。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The idea of making roads a political battleground has its roots in a by-election held in Uxbridge and South Ruislip in July. Against expectations, the Tories narrowly clung onto the seat after a backlash against an ;ultra-low-emission zone; (;ULEZ;), a scheme championed by the (Labour) mayor of London that makes drivers of the most polluting vehicles pay a daily charge. Mr Sunak's “Plan for Motorists” is a crude attempt to repeat that success nationally by tapping into other sources of road rage.

;

;Driving in Britain is often annoying, and at times miserable.该国登记的汽车数量为 3300 万辆。大约五分之四的成年人拥有驾驶执照；在首都以外，公共交通不畅，这意味着许多人每次出行都依赖汽车。 2022 年，英国 10 个最拥堵城市的司机在交通堵塞中花费了 80 小时，而美国为 50 小时，德国为 40 小时。拥堵情况将会更加严重。据英国交通部称，由于人口增长和电动汽车运行成本降低，到 2060 年交通量可能会增加 54%。

;

;Even so, Mr Sunak's claim of a “war on motorists” is hogwash.几十年来，很少有群体比司机更受宠爱。举一个明显的例子，燃油税已冻结了 13 年，给财政部造成了约 800 亿英镑（980 亿美元，几乎相当于一条高铁线路的价格）的成本。与此同时，基础设施项目被推迟，火车和公共汽车票价的上涨速度远远快于驾驶成本。结果就是经济学家所说的“诱导需求”：更多的人开车，因为开车更容易。

;

;What's more, Mr Sunak's ire is directed at policies that aim to curb the worst impacts of cars. London's ;ULEZ; is crudely designed but will save lives by making the city's air less toxic. “低交通街区”旨在使住宅区更安全；父母往往很热心。在建成区降低车速是为了防止交通事故，过去五年英国交通事故已造成 2000 多名行人死亡。研究表明，由于交通更加顺畅，20 英里每小时的方案往往会使平均行程增加不到一分钟。 9 月，威尔士政府将建成区的默认时速设为 20 英里/小时，苏纳克先生斥责这一决定不受欢迎。但爱丁堡、伦敦大部分地区和英格兰其他地区也采取了同样的政策，但没有引发起义。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Drivers can feel unfairly targeted when alternative modes of transport are unrealistic: when buses are slow, trains are unreliable and cycling is unsafe.但这是改善公共交通的一个论据。削减英国旗舰高铁项目在这方面无济于事；苏纳克先生关于允许汽车在特定时间进入公交车道的建议也不会被采纳。无论如何，限速、坑洼和停车位应该由地方议会负责，而不是来自威斯敏斯特的命令。 And fetishising motorists risks storing up bigger policy problems for the future, most obviously the need for some form of road pricing as people switch to electric vehicles.

;

;Might Mr Sunak's manoeuvre still work politically?尽管大多数英国人支持在建成区限速 20 英里/小时的想法，但大多数保守党选民反对。所谓“红墙”（保守党于 2019 年赢得的中部地区和英格兰北部的一片议席）中的选民特别喜欢开车。但这是一种有限的选举策略。绘画工党也抱怨司机受到“打击”，因为反汽车党将很难成立。尽管坑洼很烦人，但它们并不是人们希望苏纳克先生修复的主要问题。 ;■;

With food prices up 71.9% over the past year, many voters are doing just that: ;dulce et decorum est;, indeed.

;

;On September 25th Egypt decided to hold presidential elections earlier than planned. Instead of voting in the spring, Egyptians will go to the polls on December 10th. The change was not unexpected. Mr Sisi is keen to get the election out of the way before he makes painful economic decisions such as devaluing the currency. In a democracy, this would be sound politics: beggaring voters is not a ticket to victory.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The logic may seem fuzzier in Egypt, where voters are props in a democratic farce. But Mr Sisi, who led a coup in 2013, is on wobbly ground. Victory would allow him to rule until 2030. The question, which many Egyptians have begun to whisper, is whether he will last that long.

;

;There is no doubt he will win. The previous election, in 2018, had just one “opposition” candidate—who endorsed Mr Sisi. He finished third in a two-man race (spoiled ballots came second). Anyone who might have posed a real challenge was disqualified, detained or intimidated into dropping out.

;

;Four politicians have talked about running this time. None has much support. Ahmed al-Tantawy, a former ;MP; among the would-be candidates, says dozens of his backers were arrested after the government announced the election date. Citizen Lab, a Canadian cyber-watchdog, says Mr Tantawy's phone was also targeted with Predator, a sophisticated bit of spyware.

;

;The president himself entered the race on October 2nd, after his allies bused thousands of people to post offices to sign petitions endorsing his candidacy (many were bribed or compelled). “As I responded to the call of the Egyptians before, today I respond to their call again,” Mr Sisi said, striking a familiar pose: the reluctant leader pressed to service by an adoring nation.

;

;There are no reliable polls on his popularity, but it is safe to say that few Egyptians still adore him. Ordinary citizens who cheered his coup in 2013 because they craved stability now curse his handling of the economy. The currency has lost half its value in three devaluations since early 2022. Annual inflation hit a record 39.7% in August. A dollar shortage has left businesses struggling to finance imports. External debt has more than doubled, from 17% of ;GDP; in 2013 to 39% today.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Egypt signed a $3bn agreement with the ;IMF; in December (it is the fund's second-largest debtor). So far it has received only the first $347m tranche of the loan. A review meant to be finished in March would have unlocked more money. It was delayed because Egypt had made little headway on two of the fund's main demands: sell state-owned assets and float the currency.

;

;Mr Sisi's government has made half-hearted progress on the former. It sold stakes worth $1.9bn in the six months to June, barely missing its $2bn target, and hopes to shift another $5bn by June 2024. But it refuses to divest the army's economic empire, which is a big obstacle to growth because it crowds out a growing number of private firms. In August Mr Sisi held a meeting about how to grow Egypt's iron-and-steel industry. His only guests were uniformed generals; no businessmen were at the table.

;

;Floating the currency will be harder. The black-market rate is still around 20% below the official one. A weaker pound will trigger more inflation (the ;IMF; estimates it will average 32% in 2024, up from 24% this year). Even boosterish analysts at Egyptian banks doubt the central bank will get anywhere close to its 7% inflation target.

;
;;

;At the same time, Egypt will have to repay $29.2bn in external debt next year (see chart), up from $19.3bn in 2023. That is equal to 85% of its $34.4bn in foreign reserves, a figure mostly made up of deposits from wealthy Gulf states. Although they seem willing to roll over those deposits indefinitely, they are fed up with Mr Sisi and reluctant to offer him more money.

;

;So are private investors. Though interest rates have more than doubled since early 2022, to 19.75%, high inflation means real rates are negative. State-owned banks offer 9% interest on dollar deposits, returns that have a whiff of a Ponzi scheme about them. Moody's, a rating agency, has Egypt under review for a possible downgrade (it docked the country to a dismal ;B3; in February). JPMorgan Chase, a bank, might remove the country from its emerging-markets bond index because of concerns that investors cannot repatriate funds.

;

;The current-account deficit has narrowed, but Egypt still registered a $5.3bn shortfall in the nine months to March. Goldman Sachs, another bank, estimates that Egypt needs an extra $11bn in financing over the next five years. Officials hope to plug the gap with state-asset sales, borrowing from Asian countries and the ;IMF; loan. But the maths look daunting.

;

;Mr Sisi offers nothing but empty talk. In June he insisted that he would not approve another devaluation; last month he said the “end is near” for the economic crisis. He also told young people they could earn a “respectable income” by donating blood every week. Mostafa Madbouly, the prime minister, brags that Egypt has spent 9.4trn Egyptian pounds ($300bn) on infrastructure projects over the past decade. Even if that is true, much of it has been wasted on white-elephant projects, from a vast, desolate new capital city in the desert to an expansion of the Suez canal that has fallen far short of revenue projections.

;
;

;The never-ending story

;

;This election should be Mr Sisi's last: the constitution forbids a fourth term. Then again, it used to forbid seeking a third. He fixed that in a sham 2019 referendum, carving out a loophole that allowed him run again. Some of his supporters see that as a mistake. Even before the last election, they urged him to stop at two terms. “I told him he could retire as the man who saved Egypt from chaos,” one recalls. “Stand down and bring new ideas.”

;

;Friendly advice has turned to furtive scheming. Businessmen, politicians and some army officers have tried to enlist a real challenger. By rushing the poll, the president hopes to pre-empt such plots.

;

;Again, though, this is democratic logic applied to an undemocratic country. Though remembered as a revolution, the ousting of Hosni Mubarak in 2011 could also be called a coup: the army turned on the ruler to preserve the ruling system. History could be repeated, especially if soaring prices spark unrest. At small protests on the night Mr Sisi announced his candidacy people chanted “;irhal”; (leave), a popular slogan from 2011. Mr Sisi will win a new six-year term, but there are no guarantees he will be allowed to finish it. ;■;

;The solution is subsidies.这些已经大规模存在，并取得了一些成功。自2000年代初德国对太阳能提供慷慨补贴以来，由于学习效应、规模经济和中国产业政策，太阳能发电的价格已经大幅下降。 In the past decade the amount of solar energy generated in Germany every year has doubled.

;The subsidies today are somewhat larger, and more are on the way.美国的通货膨胀削减法案将在未来十年提供4000亿至1万亿美元的资金来支持太阳能、大容量电池、制氢设备和其他类型的可再生能源。日本希望为其绿色转型政策提供价值 1500 亿美元的补贴。据国际能源署称，自 2020 年以来，各国政府已宣布提供价值超过 1.3 万美元的清洁能源补贴。

;

;The new subsidies differ from those that triggered the solar revolution.德国希望更多的太阳能发电意味着更多的制造业就业机会，但它并没有以这种方式制定补贴，并且在没有就业机会的情况下获得了电池板。大多数补贴也是如此。它们的目的是安装，而不是制造。新的措施针对这两方面，它们可能会减缓而不是加速向净零的过渡。

;The subsidies contain vast numbers of “domestic content requirements”. For an American buyer to receive the full $7,500 credit for an electric vehicle (;ev); under the ;ira;, a lot of the car needs to have been made in North America. ;;I;;F 全球变暖;受到限制，世界必须忘记;化石燃料;同样快尽可能——几乎每个人都同意这一点。如何做到这一点是复杂的部分。长期以来，经济学家一直倾向于制定;碳定价;，这是欧洲于2005年推出的一种机制。这样做可以让市场确定最便宜的温室气体减排单位，从而使社会以尽可能低的成本应对气候变化。其他人，包括许多;美国政客; ，担心此类计划会因提高消费者成本而引发反弹。在乔·拜登总统的领导下，美国转而拨款数千亿美元来培育绿色供应链。

;

;然而，值得注意的是，世界其他地区现在开始变得更加欧洲化——碳价格在富裕国家和贫穷国家中蔓延。以世界第九大污染国印度尼西亚为例。尽管中国每年排放 6.2 亿吨二氧化碳当量，且飙升的能源消耗中近一半来自煤炭，但该国仍拥有绿色雄心。 9 月 26 日，在首个碳市场启动仪式上，总统佐科·维多多 (Joko Widodo) 谈到了其作为碳交易中心的前景，当地银行及时从一家地热能源公司获得了信贷。该国还在二月份推出了地方排放交易计划，要求大型燃煤电厂购买超过阈值的排放许可证。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;;

;简而言之，即使在那些更被称为污染者而不是绿色领导者的国家，情况也在发生变化。根据世界银行的数据，到 2023 年初，全球排放量的 23% 由碳价格涵盖，而 2010 年这一比例仅为 5%（见图表）。随着越来越多的国家认识到碳定价的优势，并且现有计划扩大其影响范围，这种蔓延在未来几年只会加速。 10 月 1 日，<小>;欧盟;以沉闷的名字推出了一项开创性的政策。 “碳边界调整机制”（;CBAM;）将于2026年开始对欧盟所有进口产品征收碳价，这意味着欧洲企业将有强烈的动力推动全球供应商走向绿色。

;

;碳价格的扩散通过三种方式发生。首先，政府正在创造新的市场和征税。印度尼西亚就是一个例子。如果一切按计划进行，其市场最终将与碳税结合起来。 4 月，日本启动了自愿性全国碳补偿市场，该市场将与东京现有的区域限额与交易政策协同工作。占全国污染总量40%左右的参与者将被要求披露并设定排放目标。随着时间的推移，该计划将变得更加严格，能源行业的碳配额拍卖将于 2033 年开始。同时，越南正在制定一项将于 2028 年建立的排放交易计划，其中排放量超过阈值的企业将需要通过购买积分来抵消它们。

;

;;

;

;第二，市场较为成熟的国家正在加强政策。 9月24日，中国国家气候战略中心宣布，其全球最大的碳排放权交易计划将从仅关注燃煤电厂的碳强度，转变为同时关注燃煤电厂的强度和排放总量。该计划将与休眠的碳信用市场挂钩，允许工厂通过购买可再生能源信用、种植森林或恢复红树林来履行其义务。澳大利亚于 2014 年取消了原来的碳价格，并改革了之前毫无效力的计划，即“保障机制”。自 7 月份以来，占全国排放量 28% 的大型工业设施必须比基准线每年减少 4.9% 的排放量。那些失败的企业必须购买碳补偿，其交易价格约为每吨 20 美元。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;碳市场传播的最终方式是通过跨境计划。 ;欧盟;的计划是迄今为止最先进的。在;CBAM;试点阶段，铝、水泥、电力、化肥、氢气、钢铁的进口商将需要报告“隐含”排放量（通过生产和运输产生的排放量）。然后，从2026年开始，进口商将必须缴纳相当于;欧盟;计划中这些隐含排放的碳成本与出口商在其国内市场支付的任何碳价格之间的差额的征税。各行业的免费许可证也将逐步取消，住房和交通行业将被纳入市场。

;

;其中许多计划需要时间才能产生影响。亚洲的很多项目都很脆弱，价格定得太低，无法产生有意义的变化——远低于<小>;欧盟;目前的价格 80-90 欧元（85-95 美元），而这个价格本身只接近气候经济学家的预期碳的社会成本估算。例如，中国排放交易计划覆盖的一半燃煤电厂面临着负碳价，这意味着它们实际上获得了燃烧肮脏燃料的报酬，因为它们的排放强度低于全国平均水平，中心的劳里·米利维尔塔（Lauri Myllyvirta）说。能源与清洁空气研究智库。他指出，该计划也未能激励人们从煤炭转向其他能源。

;

;在世界各地，活动人士批评企业利用补偿来沉迷于他们所谓的“绿色清洗”，即企业错误地将自己标榜为环境友好型企业。一些计划也很难证明它们已经带来了减排。 2022 年，由澳大利亚国立大学安德鲁·麦金托什 (Andrew Macintosh) 领导的一个学者团队认为，澳大利亚计划中用作碳信用额的重新造林要么不会发生，要么就会发生，无论是否支付补偿费用。此后，一项独立审查建议改变该计划的运作方式。

;

;然而，即使是有限的碳定价计划仍然有助于改变行为，原因很简单，它们鼓励排放监测。两年前启动后，中国的排放交易计划饱受欺诈困扰，据称顾问帮助企业生产假煤炭样品。今年早些时候，官员们宣布了一项打击行动，他们现在对数据的质量感到满意。尽管没有碳价格，美国公司也面临着监测排放的激励措施。拜登总统提出了一项规则，要求所有向联邦政府出售产品的企业必须披露其排放量并制定减少排放量的计划。许多大公司已经设定了自愿的净零目标，作为其营销工作的一部分。全球最大的苹果公司已承诺到 2030 年使其供应链完全实现碳中和。

;

;世界各地的制造商现在面临着准确跟踪其碳足迹的更大动力：;CBAM;。 ;欧盟;的最终目标是解决“碳泄漏”问题。在;CBAM;推出之前，欧洲的碳价意味着国内工业与脱碳计划不那么雄心勃勃的国家相比面临着额外的成本。这激励进口商从国外采购材料，即使这些投入品更脏。为了弥补这一点，<小>;欧盟;向工业生产商发放许可证。随着 ;CBAM; 的逐步采用，这些现在将被逐步淘汰。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;在试点阶段，;CBAM;只是为欧盟出口商设置了一个额外的障碍（经济学家称之为“非关税壁垒”）。为了遵守规定，欧洲公司必须报告其进口产品的隐含排放量。如果此类数据不存在，进口商必须使用;欧盟;提供的参考值。为了促使外国公司改变行为并证明其排放量较低，这些数据是基于欧盟内最肮脏企业的排放量。从 2026 年起，进口商将必须支付根据;欧盟;排放交易计划收取的隐含排放量与产品在国内支付的碳价之间的差额。

;

;未来几年，碳边境关税本身可能会倍增。澳大利亚政府最近宣布对该国的“碳泄漏”进行审查，将审查这种选择。 2021 年，美国和欧盟暂停了由唐纳德·特朗普总统发起的贸易争端，开始就“可持续钢铁和铝全球安排”进行谈判。美国希望这两个贸易伙伴对污染较严重的钢铁生产商征收共同的外部关税。由于美国没有国内碳价格，这样的政策将违反世界贸易组织的规则。但如果<小>;欧盟;和美国不能达成协议，特朗普时代的关税和<小>;欧盟;的报复措施将恢复。

;

;碳定价存在多米诺骨牌效应。一旦一个行业受到碳价格的约束，其企业自然会希望其竞争对手也面临同样的规则。因此，燃煤电厂业主将进行游说，以确保燃气电厂在公平的竞争环境中运营。出口国政府也有动力确保其国内企业在国内支付碳价格，而不是在国外支付关税。如果亚洲工厂无论如何都被迫通过诸如;CBAM;等计划来减少排放，那么其政府就会因为不征收自己的碳价而将钱留在桌面上。

;

;问题是多米诺骨牌倒下的速度是否足够快。例如，几乎没有任何排放交易计划针对住宅物业或汽车的排放，因为消费者确实会在这些方面感受到痛苦。在选择引入碳定价计划，然后使其范围更广、更有力时，政策制定者得到了大多数经济学家的坚定支持，而且进展速度比通常意识到的要快得多。但如果要最大限度地减少气候变化的影响，未来的政策制定者将需要使此类政策更具侵入性。为此，他们还必须赢得选民的支持。 ;■;
